1830 - Plan and Section of the Gilmerton Coalfield showing coal seams
1901 - Painting of George Baker Foster by H. Von Herkomer. Foster lived in Farnley Hill Corbridge during his life and was President of the North of England Mining Institute and Mechanical Engineers

Date unknown - Painting of William Cuthbert Blacket by unkown artists. Blackett, who attended Durham University lived in South Bailey and was President of the North of England Mining Institute and Mechanical Engineers

Date Unknown - Painting of George Stephenson by unkown artist. Stephenson is considered the "Father of Railways" with the "Stephenson gauge" still used as the standard for most of the world's railways

Date Unknown - Painting of John Bubble by an unkown artist. Bubble had a major influence on the development of Northen Coalfield and their saftey. Though working in many coalmines he started off his career working in Walllsend Colliery and died in Wallsend in 1843

Date unknown - Port Pirie smelting works with manager of the plant, Mr Robertson, standing outside

Date Unknown - Portrait of Nicholas Wood, Painted by R. Turner. Nicholas Wood was the first president of the North of England Insitute of Mining and Mechanical Engineers, holding the position of President from its inauguration to his death. He was born near Ryton in 1795
Date Unknown - Map to accompany the survey of Agriculture in Northumberland by Bailey and Culley

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1817 explosion at Row Pit at Harraton which killed 38 men. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1805, 1814 and 1825 explosion at Hebburn Colliery which killed 35,11 and 4 men respectively. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1812, 1813 and 1821 explosion at Felling Colliery which killed 92,22 and 52 men respectively. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1812 explosion at Row Pit at Herrington Mill Pit which killed 23 men. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1813 explosion at Hall Pit in Fatfield which killed 30 men. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1815 explosion at Sucess Pit in Newbottle which killed 57 men. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1815 and 1819 explosion at Sheriff Hill which killed 11and 35 men respectively. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1817, 1826 and 1828 explosion at the Jarrow Colliery which killed 6, 34 and 8 men respectively. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1817 and 1823 explosion at Plain Pit in Rainton which killed 26 and 57 men respectively. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1818 and 1821 explosion at Wallsend Colliery which killed 4 and 52 men respectively. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords
1829 - Handbill summarising evidence given to the House of Lords regarding the Coal trade, including questions about Wallsend Colliery
1830 - A pamphlet entitled Proceedings at Law in the Case of King V Rusell and others relative to Coal Staithes erected at Wallsend on the River Tyne

1831 - Newspaper cutting relating to a general meeting of coal owners, ship owners, merchants and others which resolved to petition both houses of Parliament for the abolition of the duty on coals exported

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1819 and 1823 explosion at George Pit in the Lumley Colliery which killed 13 and 14 men respectively. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lords

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1821 explosion at Coxlodge Pit which killed one man. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lord

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1823 explosion at Ouston Colliery in Chester-lee-street which killed 4 men. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lord

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1823 explosion at Neasham's Dolly Pit in Shiftree which killed 11 men. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lord

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1825 explosion at Juliet Pit in Fatfield which killed 11 men. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lord

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1826 explosion at Townly Pit which killed 38 men. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lord

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1826 explosion at Heworth Colliery which killed 4 men. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lord

1829 - Article about Colliery explosions from 1805 to 1828 which notes the 1826 explosion at Benwell Colliery which killed 2 men. The list comes from an adress given to the Coal Trade Investigation in a Committee of the House of Lord

Date Unkown - A document that mentions a meeting to take place at Moot Hall about the high unemployment among pitmen. A group of magistrates offering to be the mediators between  the pitmen and the coal owners
1831 - Reports of large meetings at Blyth, Blackfell and Jarrow regarding the dispute. At Blyth pitmen visited the colliery and threatened to set it on fire

1831 - Reports of large meetings at Blyth, Blackfell and Jarrow regarding the dispute. At Netherton Colliery pitmen visited the colliery and threatened to set it on fire but were prevented by quantity of ale

1812 - Plan of the area around the River Tune and Wear, marking collieries, waggon ways, major roads and vllages. The quayside area of Newcastle is highlighted on the map and shown in extra detail
1830 - An advert for the sale of Landsdale Colliery
1830 - An advert for miners and boys to work at the newly opened Acomb Colliery as well as reporting on when the coal seam was first reached
1832 - Newspaper cutting regarding the Pitmen's dispute. The newspaper talks about the impact of the dispute on Wallsend Colliery
1832 - Newspaper cutting regarding the Pitmen's dispute. The newspaper talks about a group of welsh miners who came to replace those in Jarrow Colliery who were not working due to the dispute
1832 - Newspaper cutting regarding the Pitmen's dispute. The port is highlighted as something that is being impacted by the strike.

1832- Newspaper cutting regarding the Pitmen's dispute. The clipping highlights the international impact of the dispute through the case of the Port of Sunderland and its impact on Hamberg, which caught royal attention

1832 - Newspaper cutting regarding the Pitmen's dispute. The newspaper talks about a group of welsh miners who came to replace those in Hetton Colliery who were not working due to the dispute
1832 - Newspaper cutting regarding an accident at Hetton Colliery where an explosion due to hydrogen gas killed one man
1832 - Newspaper cutting regarding a meeting of Pitmen at Boldon Fell where strike action was supported
1832 - Newspaper cutting regarding an assault at the colliery where a man called Napier was attacked after seeking police protection
1832 - Newspaper cutting regarding the murder of Ms Rairles a magistrate who was murdered by two pitmen near Jarrow Colliery
1832 - Durham Addizes report of legal cases heard in Durham. It also recorded on the judges going to service at Durham Cathedral
1832 - Durham Addizes report of legal cases heard in Durham. One of these was a murder which took place at Hetton Colliery
1832 - Durham Addizes report of legal cases heard in Durham. One of these was an assault which took place at Sheriff's Hill Colliery
1832 - Durham Addizes report of legal cases heard in Durham. One of these was a disturbance at Friar's Goose Colliery.
